ASTOUNDING NUMBER OF FOOD
SURSTITUTES USED IN GER.
MANY—MANY WILL OUTLIVE
THK WAR

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 8.—Ten thou.
sand substitute food articles have
been introduced into Germany since
the war, according to a etatement
made in the Berlin newspapers by
Professor Juckenack, a prominent
German food expert,

He mentions as the most striking
examples of successful substitution
the following: Artificial butter, eggs,
salad oll, honey, milk, coffee, tea,
Sugar, tobacco, fish, sausage, cheese
and caviar. Some of the substitutes
are directly harmful, but others are| °
30 good that they will outlive tne
war and become regular articles of
consumption, he asserts,

PROFESSIONAL CARDS

Common garden sage brewed inate
a heavy tea, with sulphur aad alcohel
added, will turn gray, streaked and

urians, Mixing the Sage Tea and Sul-
phur recipe at home, though, is treu-
blesome. _ An easier way is to. get the
ready to use preparation improved by
the addition of other fagredients,
costing about 50 cents a large bottle,
at drug stores, known as “Wyeth'’s
Sage and Sulphur Compound,” thus
avoiding a lot of muss .

While gray, faded hair is not
ful, we all desire to retain our youth.
ful appearance and attractiveness. By
darkening your hair with Wyeth’s
Sage and Sulphur Compound, a0 one
can tell, because it is dome so mater-
ally, so evenly. You just dampes' a
sponge or soft brush with it and draw
this through your hair, taking one
small strand at a-time; by morsiag
all gray hairs have disappeared. Af- |}
ter another application or two your
hair becomes dark, glossy, soft, and
luxuriant, and you appear yeare
younger. Wyeth's Sage and Sulphur
Compound is a delightful toilet requi.
site, It ig not intended for the eure,
mitigation or prevention of dissase.—
